parse.title: J.R.R. Tolkien had a cat called Grimalkin:

links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Proceedings of the J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Ent and Entwife
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{Unnamed}} {{poem infobox | title="J.R.R. Tolkien had a cat called Grimalkin:" | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names= | written=[[2 January]] of [[1969]] | revised= | published=''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'',
''[[Proceedings of the J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference]]'',
''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[J.R.R. Tolkien]], [[Wikipedia:Grimalkin|Grimalkin]], [[Wikipedia:Jakob Grimm|Herr Grimm]] }} {{Quote|Did the familiar inspire Grimm with the law, or did Grimm teach it to his cat. Given the ambiguous pronouns, did Grimalkin recite the Law to Tolkien or ''vice versa''?|[[Joe R. Christopher]], "J.R.R. Tolkien and the Clerihew"[[Patricia Reynolds]] and [[Glen H. GoodKnight]], ''[[Proceedings of the J.R.R. Tolkien Centenary Conference]]'', "Section 7: Tolkien Studies", [[1992]] ([[1995]]), pp. 263–71.}} "'''J.R.R. Tolkien had a cat called Grimalkin:'''" is the first line of a clerihew written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] as part of [[Letter 309|a letter]] to Amy Ronald on [[2 January]] of [[1969]].{{L|309}}, p. 398 ==Poem== :J.R.R. Tolkien :had a cat called Grimalkin: :once a familiar of Herr Grimm, :now he spoke the law to him. ==Background== On [[2 January]], [[1969]], [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] wrote a clerihew about himself at the end of [[Letter 309|a letter]] sent to Amy Ronald. The clerihew, along with the letter, was published for the first time in ''[[The Letters of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' in [[1981]]. In [[1995]], the clerihew was reprinted in the article "[https://dc.swosu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=2156&context=mythlore J.R.R. Tolkien and the Clerihew]", where [[Joe R. Christopher]] notes that it violates the rule that each line should begin with a capital letter. Christopher also notes that "the rhyme of the first two lines is not perfect". He explains that Tolkien's use of the name Grimalkin is interesting in that it{{Blockquote|derives from ''grey'' + ''malkin''. ''Malkin''…usually means a woman, being a variety of ''Matilda'' or ''Maud''…''grimalkin'' usually refers to a cat, especially a she-cat, although occasionally a woman. (Tolkien uses the masculine pronoun for this cat in his fourth line.)}} After giving an example of "one version of the four lines", Christopher describes "the major stresses…and the rhythms" as being "equally varied", that "''mal''- and -''mil''-" in "the second and third lines" are tied together by "a consonance", and that "''Herr'' and ''him''" in "the third and fourth lines" connect through "alliteration". He also notes that "the ''gr'' of ''Grimalkin'' echoes the sound in the stressed syllable ''Grimm''", which is significant because it "connects two of the important terms". Christopher adds that "the verse…is perhaps too mysterious to be a good clerihew, but the play with Grimm's law produces a surprising shift from witchcraft to philology and in that sense may be humorous". In [[September]] of [[2024]], the poem was reprinted in Appendix I in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'', where [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] suggest in their commentary that Tolkien's use of the name Grimalkin could also mean "friend, associate".{{CP|A1}}, "Clerihews" ==Inspiration== [[Joe R. Christopher]] comments "that the first discovered use of a form of ''grimalkin'' is in [[Wikipedia:William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] ''[[Wikipedia:Macbeth|Macbeth]]''" in 1605 where the name "Gray-Malkin refers to a Fiend". Christopher further notes that "the dotty or whimsical aspect of this clerihew" is that Tolkien "does not mean anything serous by saying that he and Jakob Grimm…had the same familiar". In using the name Grimalkin, Tolkien may possibly have been inspired by "[[Wikipedia:John Masefield|John Masefield's]] ''[[Wikipedia:The Midnight Folk|The Midnight Folk]]'', a children's book of [[1927]]", where Greymalkin is the name of an evil cat. Since Tolkien spelled the name as Grimalkin:{{blockquote|the law that is spoken could be taken as some…supernatural rule or simply the stubbornness of cats demanding food, for example; but the actual reference no doubt is to a philological rule about the changes in the Indo-European language when German developed out of it.…This rule is known as Grimm’s Law. Did the familiar inspire Grimm with the law, or did Grimm teach it to his cat. Given the ambiguous pronouns, did Grimalkin recite the Law to Tolkien or ''vice versa''? (Under the general rule of thumb that a pronoun refers back to the most immediate noun, presumably the former - but it is not quite certain.) The clerihew has an uncertain meter in the first two lines. As has been said of an earlier clerihew, it is difficult to know how one should read those opening initials.}} {{References}} {{Poems}} [[Category:Limericks and clerihews]]
